item.title: Somalia: Centralized High School Exams Taking Hold
item.description: Private education networks were formed by local business leaders to fill the void left by the government. Over time, the networks created a cartel-like chokehold over the entire education system. They resisted any form of regulatory supervision or reform. Each network operated its own set of scattered, incoherent and low quality curriculums, resulting in the proliferation of substandard examinations and certifications.
